In a Mars Hill forum posting, the pastors were not named, but they reported that one was fired for "displaying an unhealthy distrust in the senior leadership" and the other for "disregarding the accepted elder protocol for the bylaw deliberation period" and "verbally attacking the lead pastor [Driscoll]."{{cite web|url = http://www.thestranger.com/seattle/church-or-cult/Content?oid=12172001|title = Church or Cult? The Control-Freaky Ways of Mars Hill Church|date = February 1, 2012|website = [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|last = Kiley|first = Brendan}} The morning after Petry and Meyer were fired, Driscoll said to his pastors and other church leaders at a conference: "Yesterday we fired two elders for the first time in the history of Mars Hill.... They were off mission, so now they're unemployed. This will be the defining issue as to whether or not you succeed or fail. I've read enough of the New Testament to know that occasionally [[Paul the Apostle|Paul [the Apostle]]] puts somebody in the wood chipper." In addition to the loss of their jobs, both were put on ecclesiastical trials to review their church membership. Petry was charged by Driscoll and the other elders with "lack of trust and respect for spiritual authority" and "improper use of confidential information", the latter charge because Petry had discussed the bylaw changes with church deacon Rob Smith, who was not part of the council of elders but had been asked to join. Petry was permitted to respond to the charges, but was not allowed to attend his full trial. The elders came to a unanimous conclusion that Petry was no longer qualified to be a church elder. Driscoll urged his congregation to shun Petry's family.{{Cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2014/08/23/us/mark-driscoll-is-being-urged-to-leave-mars-hill-church.html|title = A Brash Style That Filled Pews, Until Followers Had Their Fill: Mark Driscoll Is Being Urged to Leave Mars Hill Church|last = Paulson|first = Michael|date = August 22, 2014|work = [[The New York Times]]|accessdate = August 27, 2014}} Meyer was given a "gentler" ecclesiastical trial but chose to resign. Rob Smith had written an email to the elders calling for a fair trial for Petry and Meyer; Smith said that in response, Driscoll told his congregants to stop giving to Agathos, an independent economic development charity that Smith also ran, causing donations to drop by 80 percent. ==== Repercussions ==== Within a year of the changes, Lief Moi, co-founder of Mars Hill and a close friend of Driscoll, left Mars Hill and started a pizzeria.{{Cite news|title = Coming full circle|date = December 6, 2012|last = Ball|first = Linda|url = http://www.issaquahreporter.com/news/182419011.html|newspaper = [[Issaquah Reporter]]}} He later explained that he was disillusioned with the bylaw changes and fallout; he felt it best to "leave quietly" rather than "add to the difficulty" that the restructuring had caused. He repudiated his past actions and met with Petry and Meyer to apologize for "not doing more to stand up for them."{{Cite web|url = http://repentantpastor.com/confessions/lief-mois-confession-2/|title = Lief Moi's Confession|date = March 29, 2014|accessdate = August 27, 2014|website = Repentant Pastor|publisher = |last = Moi|first = Lief|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140805151842/http://repentantpastor.com/confessions/lief-mois-confession-2/|archivedate = August 5, 2014|df = mdy-all}} In 2014, Petry, Smith, and Moi all joined and, in some cases, organized online protests against Driscoll. Commentators linked the summer 2014 "unrest" at Mars Hill to the structural changes of 2007 along with other developments in Driscoll's career.{{Cite news|url = http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2024380355_marshillxml.html|title = Driscoll to take break from Mars Hill pulpit|last = Broom|first = Jack|date = August 24, 2014|work = [[Seattle Times]]|accessdate = August 27, 2014}} === ABC Nightline special (2009) === In March 2009, Driscoll was involved in an [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] ''[[Nightline]] ''debate entitled, ''"Does Satan Exist?"'' Driscoll and [[Annie Lobert]], founder of the [[Hookers for Jesus]] Christian ministry, argued for the existence of the devil against [[Deepak Chopra]], philosopher, and [[Carlton Pearson]], former fundamentalist minister and author of "The Gospel of Inclusion." A commentator described the debate as "contentious", with all participants taking "uncompromising" positions. Driscoll argued that a belief in both Satan and God was an essential tenet of Christianity. Driscoll has also been featured on the program discussing other topics including the [[Ten Commandments]] and sex.{{cite news|last=Brown|first=Ely|last2=Johnson|first2=Eric|title=''Nightline'' Face-Off: Does Satan Exist?|url=http://abcnews.go.com/Nightline/story?id=7071125|accessdate=April 9, 2014|newspaper=[[ABC News]]|date=March 13, 2009}}{{cite video | url=http://marshill.com/media/in-the-news/nightline-satan-debate| title=Nightline Satan Debate | publisher=Mars Hill Church | date=March 26, 2009 | archiveurl =https://web.archive.org/web/20111017103201/http://marshill.com/media/in-the-news/nightline-satan-debate |deadurl=yes |archivedate=October 17, 2011 |accessdate=December 24, 2016}} === Haiti relief (2010) === After the catastrophic [[2010 Haiti earthquake]], Driscoll and [[James MacDonald (pastor)|James MacDonald]] founded Churches Helping Churches to help churches rebuild after catastrophic natural disasters. They help to rebuild dozens of churches in Haiti and Japan.{{cite web|title=Mission Accomplished: Churches Helping Churches|url=http://www.harvestbible.org/10780/ministry/ministry_id/352425/Churches-Helping-Churches|work=Harvest Bible Chapel|accessdate=April 15, 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140416182213/http://www.harvestbible.org/10780/ministry/ministry_id/352425/Churches-Helping-Churches|archivedate=April 16, 2014|df=mdy-all}} Driscoll first flew to Haiti shortly after the earthquake, and set up a partnership between his church and Jean F. E. St. Cyr, a Haitian pastor. Mars Hill Church donated $1.7 million in medical supplies.{{cite web |url=http://religion.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/19/seattle-pastor-returns-to-haiti/ |title=Seattle pastor returns to Haiti|last=Marrapodi|first=Eric|work=[[CNN]] Belief Blog|date=January 19, 2011 |accessdate=December 24, 2016}} === Resignation from Acts 29 and The Gospel Coalition (2012) === On March 29, 2012, Driscoll resigned as President of Acts 29 and from the Council of The Gospel Coalition,{{Cite journal|title = Driscoll Drops Acts 29 & Gospel Coalition|date = March 30, 2012|last = Scaramanga|first = Url|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/parse/2012/march/driscoll-drops-acts-29-gospel-coalition.html|journal = PARSE: Leadership Journal|publisher = Christianity Today International}} turning his responsibilities over to [[Matt Chandler (pastor)|Matt Chandler]].{{Cite news|title = Mark Driscoll Steps Down as Leader of Acts 29; Resigns From Gospel Coalition|date = March 29, 2012|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscoll-steps-down-as-leader-of-acts-29-resigns-from-gospel-coalition-72283/|last = Murashko|first = Alex|work = [[Christian Post]]}} Commenting on the transition, Chandler said, "[the Acts 29 board was] running a network of 422 churches on six continents the same way when it was 80 to 100 churches on one continent."{{Cite news|last=Murashko|first=Alex|title = No 'Vision Shift' After Mark Driscoll Leaves Acts 29 Leadership|date = April 11, 2012|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/no-vision-shift-after-mark-driscoll-leaves-acts-29-leadership-73047/|work = [[Christian Post]]}} Chandler also planned to disentangle Acts 29 from Mars Hill Church; prior to Driscoll's departure, Acts 29 was primarily funded by Mars Hill. By mid-2014, Driscoll was no longer on the board of Acts 29.{{cite web|url = http://www.acts29network.org/about/leadership/|title = The Acts 29 Board|accessdate = April 16, 2014|website = [[Acts 29]] | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140325113427/http://www.acts29network.org/about/leadership/ | archivedate = March 25, 2014}} Driscoll was a founding member of The Gospel Coalition, a fellowship of reformed evangelical churches. On his departure, he wrote he had no "relational conflict with anyone and no disagreement theologically"; rather, he explained that he was reorganizing his priorities and could not keep up with all of his commitments. Driscoll indicated that he intended to devote more of his efforts to Mars Hill Church, more time to his family, and less time to travel.{{Cite web|url = http://pastormark.tv/2012/03/28/what-is-next-for-me|title = What's Next for Me|date = March 28, 2012|last = Driscoll|first = Mark|website = Pastor Mark Driscoll|type = blog|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140501092421/http://pastormark.tv/2012/03/28/what-is-next-for-me|archivedate = May 1, 2014|df = mdy-all}} === Formal charges filed by former elder Dave Kraft (2013) === In May 2013, now former Mars Hill elder Dave Kraft filed formal charges (under Mars Hill Church bylaws) of "mistreatment" against Mark Driscoll and other leaders at Mars Hill. He specifically accused Driscoll of being "domineering, verbally violent, arrogant, and quick-tempered." Kraft further argued that this "established pattern of... behavior" disqualified Driscoll from church leadership.Specifically, Kraft said that Driscoll's behavior violated three different Bible passages that give the qualifications for church elders. Under Mars Hill bylaws, Driscoll is required to meet the biblical standards of a church elder. The passages are: {{bibleref2|1 Timothy|3}}, {{bibleref2|Titus|1}}, and {{bibleref2|1 Peter|5}}. Mars Hill Church's Board of Advisors and Accountability responded, saying that they sent one hundred letters to former elders and staff in an effort to substantiate Kraft's charges. They received eighteen responses, which they reviewed, and determined them to be "non-disqualifying" with respect to Driscoll's leadership position. However, the Board did initiate a "reconciliation process" to address "many offenses and hurts that are still unresolved."{{Cite news|title = Charges Against Mark Driscoll and Mars Hill Church Executive Elders 'Non-Disqualifying,' Says Advisory Board|date = March 27, 2014|last = Murashko|first = Alex|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/charges-against-mark-driscoll-and-mars-hill-church-executive-elders-non-disqualifying-says-advisory-board-116924/|work = [[Christian Post]]}} Dave Kraft worked at Mars Hill from 2005 to 2013 and was Driscoll's personal "coach" during that time.{{Cite news|url = http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2024534198_marshillprofilexml.html|title = The rise and fall of Mars Hill Church|last = Welch|first = Craig|date = September 13, 2014|work = [[Seattle Times]]|accessdate = September 14, 2014}} === Former leaders and members protest Driscoll (2014) === [[Michael Paulson]], writing for ''[[The New York Times]]'', wrote that while Driscoll has endured criticism from the [[American political left]] and [[liberal Christianity]] for many years, recent years leading up to and including 2014 saw the rise of criticism from [[Evangelicalism#Diversity|conservative Christians]], including Driscoll's former "allies and supporters." According to the ''[[Seattle Times]]'', Janet Mefferd's plagiarism accusations were a "crucial turning point" that drew outside interest into Mars Hill's internal affairs, and prompted inquiries from new critics about the church and how it handled its finances. After hearing of Mefferd's plagiarism accusations, [[evangelical Christian]] and [[Grove City College]] psychology professor [[Warren Throckmorton]] took interest and became a prominent critic of Driscoll and Mars Hill, documenting other examples of perceived plagiarism, abuse reported by former Mars Hill members, and questionable uses of church finances. ==== "Repentant Pastors" ==== On March 29, 2014, four former Mars Hill elders (Kyle Firstenberg, Dave Kraft, Scott Mitchell, and co-founder Lief Moi) created a blog titled "Repentant Pastor" and posted online "confessions and apologies" related to their leadership roles in Mars Hill. In a joint statement, they wrote, "we recognize and confess that Mars Hill has hurt many people within the Mars Hill community, as well as those outside the community."{{Cite web|url = http://repentantpastor.com/|title = Home Page|date = |accessdate = May 12, 2014|website = Repentant Pastor|publisher =}} ''Salon'' summarized the statements, writing that the former leaders emphasized their failures to "rein Driscoll in" and their complicity with Driscoll's "autocratic" management style. Firstenberg wrote that while the church appeared to flourish, employees lived in constant stress, and "success was to be attained regardless of human and moral cost." Firstenberg added:
The reputation Driscoll got for being the cussing pastor simply because he used harsh language from the pulpit was nothing compared to the swearing and abusive language he used daily with staff. When people asked me how I liked working at Mars Hill, I would simply say, "It is a great church to attend, but I wouldn’t recommend working here." It was well known with the staff that what was preached on Sunday was not lived out Monday morning with the staff.
Lief Moi described his own behavior at Mars Hill as "driven by [[narcissism]] and anti-social tendencies."{{Cite web|url = http://repentantpastor.com/confessions/lief-mois-confession-2/|title = Lief Moi's Confession|date = March 29, 2014|accessdate = February 28, 2015|website = Repentant Pastor|publisher = |last = Moi|first = Lief|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140805151842/http://repentantpastor.com/confessions/lief-mois-confession-2/|archivedate = August 5, 2014|df = mdy-all}} ==== Driscoll addresses former members' complaints ==== In a recorded message shown to church members on July 27, 2014, Driscoll discussed the various controversies of 2014. He said that he could "not address some members' discontent... because the complaints were anonymous." According to Rob Smith, former program director at the church, the anonymity assertion "really touched a nerve" with former members. In response, dissenters organized a [[Facebook]] group called "Dear Pastor Mark & Mars Hill: We Are Not Anonymous."{{Cite news|url = http://www.kirotv.com/news/news/former-members-protest-mars-hill-church/ngrWp/|title = Former Members Protest Mars Hill Church, Pastors rant revealed|date = July 30, 2014|work = [[KIRO-TV]]|accessdate = August 5, 2014}} ==== Public demonstration at Mars Hill Church ==== The following Sunday, "dozens of demonstrators"{{Cite news|url = http://www.king5.com/news/local/Former-members-protest-Mars-Hill-pastor-269759231.html|title = Former members protest Mars Hill church pastor|last = Gibb|first = Abbey|date = August 3, 2014|work = [[King-TV]]|accessdate = August 5, 2014|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140808064840/http://www.king5.com/news/local/Former-members-protest-Mars-Hill-pastor-269759231.html|archivedate = August 8, 2014|df = mdy-all}} organized and picketed the Mars Hill Church Bellevue campus (where Driscoll preaches live), calling for Driscoll's resignation. Demonstrators carried placards reading "We Are Not Anonymous" and "Question Mark", and accused Driscoll of bullying, misogyny, inadequate transparency in church finances, and harsh discipline of members. Driscoll was away for his annual summer vacation. A church elder, Anthony Iannicielo, responded that the criticism of Driscoll and Mars Hill "goes with the territory" of running a large church with a long history. In a pre-recorded message, Driscoll said that he had been deliberately "rather silent" during the criticism, that he found it "a little overwhelming and a bit confusing", and indicated that he had no intention of resigning.{{Cite news|url = http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2024235297_marshillprotestxml.html|title = Mars Hill protesters call for pastor's resignation|last = Mapes|first = Lynda V.|date = August 3, 2014|work = [[Seattle Times]]|accessdate = August 4, 2014}} ==== Removal from Acts 29 Network ==== On August 8, 2014, the board of Acts 29 removed both Driscoll and Mars Hill Church from membership. Chairman [[Matt Chandler (pastor)|Matt Chandler]] wrote, "it is our conviction that the nature of the accusations against Mark, most of which have been confirmed by him, make it untenable and unhelpful to keep Mark [Driscoll] and Mars Hill [Church] in our network." The board of directors of Acts 29 expressed gratitude for Driscoll's work with the Network as co-founder and former President, but declared his recent actions "ungodly and disqualifying behavior." To Driscoll, they wrote, "our board and network have been the recipients of... dozens of fires directly linked to you... we are naturally associated with you and feel that this association discredits the network and is a major distraction." They further advised him to "step down from ministry for an extended time and seek help."{{Cite web|url = http://www.acts29network.org/acts-29-blog/a-message-from-the-board-of-acts-29-concerning-mark-driscoll-and-mars-hill-church/|title = A Message from the Board of Acts 29 concerning Mark Driscoll and Mars Hill Church|date = August 8, 2014|accessdate = |website = |publisher = Acts 29|last = |first = |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20150211134928/http://www.acts29network.org/acts-29-blog/a-message-from-the-board-of-acts-29-concerning-mark-driscoll-and-mars-hill-church/|archivedate = February 11, 2015}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.worldmag.com/2014/08/acts_29_to_mark_driscoll_resign_and_seek_help|title = Acts 29 to Mark Driscoll: Resign and seek help: The church-planting network board calls on its co-founder to step down as pastor of Mars Hill Church|last = Smite|first = Warren Cole|date = August 8, 2014|work = [[World magazine]]|accessdate = August 12, 2014}} Acts 29 had attempted to "lean on" the Mars Hill's Board of Advisors and Accountability (BOAA) to discipline Driscoll, but lost confidence in the board. The BOAA had been set up by Driscoll as his accountability board, rather than the elders of the church. (Members of the BOAA were for the most part professional clergy and businessmen who were not members of the church and hand picked by Driscoll.) The previous month, evangelical leaders and Acts 29 associates Paul Tripp and James MacDonald resigned from the BOAA. Religion correspondent [[Sarah Pulliam Bailey]] described Acts 29's decision as "unusual" since "ministries usually leave matters of church discipline up to local churches."{{Cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/11/mark-driscoll-books-lifeway_n_5669700.html|title = Megapastor Mark Driscoll's Books Pulled From Major Christian Store In Wake Of Scandal|last = Bailey|first = Sarah P.|date = August 11, 2014|work = [[Huffington Post]]|accessdate = August 13, 2014}} BOAA Chairman Michael Van Skaik responded, "Men, I told the lead pastors... that we are making real progress in addressing the serious reconciliation and unhealthy culture issues that have been part of Mars Hill Church for way too long. And we are...." He further added that Acts 29 leaders did not contact Mars Hill before acting, and that Driscoll had "changed his ways", and described Acts 29's actions as "divisive." Van Skaik also addressed the formal charges brought against Driscoll under the Mars Hill bylaws, writing "the formal charges that were filed were serious, were taken seriously, and were not dismissed by the board lightly."{{Cite news|url = http://komonews.com/archive/mars-hill-responds-admits-unhealthy-culture-issues|title = Mars Hill responds, admits ‘unhealthy culture issues’|last = Connelly|first = Joel|date = August 9, 2014|work = [[Komo News]]|accessdate = July 21, 2016}} ==== Hiatus from ministry ==== On August 24, 2014, Driscoll announced he would take a six-week "extended focus break" from his pastorship while charges against him were investigated.{{cite journal |first=Morgan |last=Lee |title=Mark Driscoll Steps Down While Mars Hill Investigates Charges |magazine=[[Christianity Today]] |date=August 24, 2014 |accessdate=August 24, 2014 |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/august/mark-driscoll-steps-down-while-mars-hill-investigates-charg.html}} Later that week, a letter signed by nine current Mars Hill pastors which severely criticized Driscoll was leaked to the public. The letter, written days before Driscoll stepped down, urged him to step down from all aspects of ministry. It included a quote from "internationally recognized" author, pastor and former BOAA member Paul Tripp saying, "This is without a doubt, the most abusive, coercive ministry culture I’ve ever been involved with."{{cite news |first=Sarah Pulliam |last=Bailey |title=Pastors' letter on Mark Driscoll: Step down from all aspects of ministry and leadership |date=August 28, 2014 |accessdate=August 28, 2014 |work=[[Religion News Service]] |url=http://www.religionnews.com/2014/08/28/mars-hill-pastors-letter-mark-driscoll-step-down-ministry-leadership/}} One of the pastors who signed the letter was fired five days later for "rebellion against the church."{{cite news |first1=Alison |last1=Morrow |first2=Alex |last2=Rozier |title=Mars Hill pastor terminated from position |url=http://www.king5.com/story/news/local/2014/08/28/mars-hill-pastor-terminated/14767793/ |work=KING 5 News |date=August 29, 2014 |accessdate=September 1, 2014}} By September 9, eight of the nine pastors who signed the letter had resigned or been terminated, including worship director [[Dustin Kensrue]].{{cite web |url=http://www.christiantoday.com/article/seismic.shift.in.mars.hill.leadership.as.three.more.pastors.step.down/40322.htm |title=Seismic shift in Mars Hill leadership as three more pastors step down |last=Lodge |first=Carey |date=September 5, 2014 |website=[[Christian Today]] |accessdate=September 5, 2014}} The last of the nine pastors was demoted from pastor to lay elder.{{Cite web|url = http://www.christiantoday.com/article/mass.exodus.for.mars.hill.pastors.who.criticised.mark.driscolls.leadership/41415.htm|title = Mass exodus for Mars Hill pastors who criticised Mark Driscoll's leadership|date = October 8, 2014|accessdate = October 8, 2014|website = [[Christianity Today]]|publisher = |last = Lodge|first = Carey}} Driscoll did not return at the end of the planned six weeks; after seven weeks, he announced his resignation. ==== Staff layoffs and closure of church branches ==== [[File:Mars Hill Church banners displayed at Daniels Recital Hall.jpg|thumb|Mars Hill Church's downtown Seattle campus, one of the first locations to close prior to Driscoll's resignation. The building is the historic [[Daniels Recital Hall]], a former Methodist Episcopal church.]] On September 7, 2014 (the second week of Driscoll's hiatus), Mars Hill officials, citing "financial pressures in the wake of recent negative media attention", announced layoffs and closures of a few church branches. Weekly attendance at the start of the year for all branches was 12,000–13,000, but had dropped to 8,000–9,000. Donations also had a "steep decline." In response, the church planned to lay off "30 to 40 percent" of their 100 paid staff members, and close their downtown Seattle branch and [[University District, Seattle|University District]] branch, consolidating both congregations into the [[Ballard, Seattle|Ballard]] location. Two other branches outside Washington state were marked for possible closure if their finances did not improve.{{Cite news|url = http://seattletimes.com/html/localnews/2024485113_marshillxml.html|title = More trouble for Mars Hill: cutting jobs, merging churches|last = Welch|first = Craig|date = September 7, 2014|work = [[Seattle Times]]|accessdate = September 8, 2014}} Mars Hill also announced the resignation of Sutton Turner, executive elder since 2011, effective at the end of September 2014.{{Cite web|url = https://marshill.com/2014/09/19/the-weekly-9-19-14|title = The Weekly | 9.19.14: Update from the BoAA|date = September 19, 2014|accessdate = September 19, 2014|website = Mars Hill Church|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141020065942/https://marshill.com/2014/09/19/the-weekly-9-19-14|archivedate = October 20, 2014|dead-url = yes|df = mdy-all}} ==== Other repercussions ==== [[LifeWay Christian Resources]], a Christian bookseller and publishing arm of the [[Southern Baptist Convention]], announced on August 10, 2014 that they suspended sales of Driscoll's books. Marty King, communications director for LifeWay, said, "[we] are not selling Mark Driscoll's books while we assess the situation regarding his ministry."{{Cite news|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/august/lifeway-stops-selling-mark-driscolls-books-at-180-christian.html|title = LifeWay Stops Selling Mark Driscoll's Books at 180 Christian Stores|last = Moon|first = Ruth|date = August 10, 2014|work = [[Christianity Today]]: Gleanings|accessdate = August 12, 2014}} King identified Acts 29's call for Driscoll to step down as "certainly a part" of their decision, along with the "cumulative effect" of other allegations against Driscoll. Driscoll was removed from the speaker roster of several planned ''Act Like Men ''conferences, which includes other Acts 29 speakers and past Driscoll associates, including James MacDonald and Matt Chandler.{{Cite news|url = http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlepolitics/2014/08/12/driscoll-disappears-from-agenda-of-act-like-men-conferences/|title = Driscoll disappears from agenda of Act Like Men conferences|last = Connelly|first = Joel|date = August 12, 2014|work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|accessdate = August 12, 2014}} He was also removed as closing speaker at the [[Gateway Church Conference]], an annual gathering of thousands of evangelical pastors.{{Cite news|url = http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlepolitics/2014/08/15/mark-driscoll-removed-as-closing-speaker-at-big-church-conference/#25601101=0|title = Mark Driscoll removed as closing speaker at big church conference|last = Connelly|first = Joel|date = August 15, 2014|work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|accessdate = August 19, 2014}} Mars Hill Church also cancelled their own Resurgence 2014 conference, planned for October 2014, since several planned speakers had cut ties with Driscoll.{{Cite news|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/mars-hill-cancels-annual-resurgence-conference-amid-controversy-surrounding-mark-driscoll-124878/|title = Mars Hill Cancels Annual Resurgence Conference Amid Controversy Surrounding Mark Driscoll|last = Martinez|first = Jessica|date = August 15, 2014|work = [[Christian Post]]|accessdate = August 15, 2014}} === Resignation from Mars Hill Church === In the fall of 2014, a group of elders released a report on an investigation into accusations of bullying and intimidating behavior by Driscoll made by 21 former church elders. The investigation involved "some 1,000 hours of research, interviewing more than 50 people and preparing 200 pages of information." The report concluded that Driscoll had never been charged with "immorality, illegality or heresy," and considered "some of the accusations against Pastor Mark to be altogether unfair or untrue." Additionally, the report found that many of the "other charges had previously been addressed by Pastor Mark, privately and publicly. Indeed, he had publicly confessed and apologized for a number of the charges against him, some of which occurred as long as 14 years ago."{{cite web|url=https://www.marshillsbus.com/2014/10/15/pastor-mark-driscolls-resignation| title= Pastor Mark Driscoll's Resignation|accessdate=14 October 2014}}{{dead link|date=July 2015}} However, elders did find "bullying" and "patterns of persistent sinful behavior" by Driscoll.{{Cite news|url =http://blog.seattlepi.com/seattlepolitics/2014/10/19/the-pastors-persistent-sinful-behavior-why-driscoll-quit-mars-hill/|title =The pastor’s "persistent sinful behavior": Why Driscoll quit Mars Hill|last = Connelly|first = Joel|date = Oct 19, 2014|work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|accessdate = Oct 19, 2014}} The Board also concluded that Driscoll had "been guilty of arrogance, responding to conflict with a quick temper and harsh speech, and leading the staff and elders in a domineering manner", but was not charged with anything immoral or illegal. Driscoll maintained that he had not disqualified himself from ministry. Church leadership crafted a "restoration" plan to help Driscoll and save the church. Instead, Driscoll declined the restoration plan and resigned on October 14, 2014, citing concerns for his health and safety. His resignation came as a "surprise" to the church's Board of Overseers, who said in a statement that they had not asked Driscoll for his resignation.{{Cite web|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/october/goodbye-mars-hill-multisite-church-dissolve-mark-driscoll.html|title = Goodbye, Mars Hill: Mark Driscoll's Multisite Empire Will Sell Properties and Dissolve|date = October 31, 2014|accessdate = November 8, 2014|website = [[Christianity Today]]|publisher = |last = Lee|first = Morgan}} The journalist Ruth Graham wrote that "there was no single disgrace or crime that brought Driscoll down. Instead, it was a series of accusations: of plagiarism, crudeness, a bullying management style, unseemly consolidation of power, and squishy book-promotion ethics, to name a few." Theology professor Anthony Bradley remarked that while denominational churches have continuity after the departure of prominent leaders, Mars Hill Church was nondenominational and largely built on Driscoll's personal charisma. On October 20, 2014, six days after his resignation, Driscoll, at the invitation of mega-church leader, Robert Morris, spoke at Morris's Gateway Conference saying that, leading up to his resignation, he and his family were harassed and he had received death threats.{{cite web|url=http://www.religionnews.com/2014/10/21/mark-driscoll-back-offers-spontaneous-address/|title=Mark Driscoll speaks for first time after resigning Seattle megachurch|accessdate=October 21, 2014}} Driscoll subsequently appeared at other conferences and churches. == The Trinity Church in Scottsdale, Arizona == On July 27, 2015, Driscoll announced that his new ministry had purchased the mailing list and assets of ''The Resurgence'' from Mars Hill Church and that he and his family had moved to the Phoenix area.{{Cite web|url = http://markdriscoll.org/driscoll-family-update/|title = Driscoll Family Update|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = Driscoll|first = Mark}} On February 1, 2016, the Driscolls announced the opening of their new church: The Trinity Church in Scottsdale, Arizona.{{Cite web|title = Mark Driscoll Is Starting A New Church in Arizona|url = http://www.relevantmagazine.com/slices/mark-driscoll-starting-new-church-arizona|website = RELEVANT Magazine|accessdate = February 2, 2016}}{{Cite news|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscoll-to-start-new-church-in-phoenix-152705/|title = Mark Driscoll to Start New Church in Phoenix|last = Porter|first = Kevin|date = December 17, 2015|work = Christian Post|accessdate = December 18, 2015|via =}}{{Cite web|title = Announcing The Trinity Church Plant in Phoenix|url = http://markdriscoll.org/announcing-the-trinity-church-plant-in-phoenix/|website = Pastor Mark Driscoll|accessdate = February 2, 2016|language = en-US}} Commentators including Warren Throckmorton observed that the new church's website makes no reference to Driscoll's "controversial" history at Mars Hill, while the staff roster include two former Mars Hill employees. Texas megachurch pastors [[Robert Morris (pastor)|Robert Morris]] and Jimmy Evans are on the church's board.{{Cite web|title = Former Mars Hill pastor Mark Driscoll to start new church in Phoenix|url = http://www.seattletimes.com/seattle-news/former-mars-hill-pastor-to-start-new-church-in-phoenix/|website = The Seattle Times|date = February 1, 2016|accessdate = February 8, 2016}} == Public image == According to the ''Seattle Times'', "preaching and communicating lies at the heart of Driscoll's draw."{{cite news |last = Tu|first = Janet|title = Pastor Mark packs 'em in|url = http://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?date=20031128&slug=pacific-preacher30|accessdate = May 31, 2016|work = [[Seattle Times]]|date = November 28, 2003}} According to Mars Hill, at his peak online audiences generated 15 million views of his sermons per year.{{Cite web|url = https://marshill.com/pastors/mark-driscoll|title = Pastor Mark Driscoll|date = |accessdate = October 11, 2014|website = [[Mars Hill Church]]|publisher = |deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20141018022204/https://marshill.com/pastors/mark-driscoll|archivedate = October 18, 2014|df = mdy-all}} In another ''Seattle Times'' article, Driscoll is described as a "hipster preacher" who used "charisma and combativeness." Driscoll has been described as a "gifted orator" and "charismatic leader." People call him a very compelling speaker, "gifted" and "dynamic and funny, with a potent mix of reverence for Jesus and irreverence for everything else." His public speaking style, he says, is influenced by stand-up comedians like [[Chris Rock]].{{Sfn | Driscoll | 2006 |p = 70}} [[Crosscut.com]] described his presentation style as follows: "Pacing the stage at the main Ballard campus, he delivered a sermon on marriage roles as he saw them set forth in the [[Song of Songs|Song of Solomon]]. He told stories from his own marriage, offered statistics, and dropped jokes without their feeling forced. Every few minutes he would sniff in a thoughtful, practiced sort of way. This untucked, down-to-earth demeanor was the opposite of a huckster televangelist, but polished in its own way. It makes the guy easy to listen to."{{cite web |last = Hiskes|first = Jonathan|url = http://crosscut.com/2008/10/30/religion/18602/|title = Evangelism meets Seattle: the view from Mars Hill|date = November 30, 2008|accessdate = April 10, 2014|work = [[Crosscut.com|Crosscut]]}} Rob Wall, a professor at Seattle Pacific University, links the success of Mars Hill Church to Mark Driscoll's direct answers to complicated spiritual questions: "His style of public rhetoric is very authoritative. Whether it's about the Bible, or about culture, he is very clear and definitive."{{cite web |url = http://www.ballardnewstribune.com/articles/2008/07/14/news/local_news/news03.txt|title = Mars Hill Church one of nation's fastest growing|date = July 14, 2008|first = Rose|last = Egge|publisher = Ballard News-Tribune|accessdate = October 4, 2008|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080803000401/http://www.ballardnewstribune.com/articles/2008/07/14/news/local_news/news03.txt|archivedate = August 3, 2008}} In 2009, ''[[The New York Times Magazine]]'' called Driscoll "one of the most admired—and reviled—figures among evangelicals nationwide." In 2011, ''Preaching'' magazine named him one of the 25 most influential [English-speaking] pastors of the past 25 years.{{cite web|url = http://www.preaching.com/resources/articles/11629162/page-5/|title = The 25 Most Influential Pastors of the Past 25 Years|accessdate = April 9, 2014|last = Duduit|first = Michael|website = Preaching|publisher = [[Salem Publishing]]|year = 2011}} In 2014, [[Forbes]] called Driscoll "one of the nation’s most prominent and celebrated pastors."{{Cite news|url = https://www.forbes.com/sites/robasghar/2014/09/16/mars-hill-cautionary-tales-from-the-enron-of-american-churches/|title = Mars Hill: Cautionary Tales From The Enron Of American Churches|last = Asghar|first = Rob|date = September 16, 2014|work = [[Forbes]]|accessdate = September 17, 2014}} Driscoll is described in a 2014 profile by ''[[Salon (magazine)|Salon]]'' as being the center of a [[cult of personality]], and of using controversy to increase his visibility. ''Salon'' has also described "[sex] talk fused with God talk, or titillation more broadly, [as] a key component of the Driscoll brand," adding: "Driscoll’s stage persona at times has included tight jeans and an extra button open on the shirt. He once greeted a crowd at the University of Washington by reporting that he had gotten his genitals caught in his zipper before the show and that he would be stopping on time because his wife was at home waiting for him with a cream pie". == Controversy == ''See also: {{slink|Mark Driscoll|Sexuality}}'' === Comments on Ted Haggard === When evangelical pastor [[Ted Haggard]] resigned from church leadership after a sex scandal involving a male escort, Driscoll provoked an uproar by posting the following comment on his blog: "A wife who lets herself go and is not sexually available to her husband in the ways that the [[Song of Songs]] is so frank about is not responsible for her husband's sin, but she may not be helping him either."{{cite web |last=Hiskes|first=Jonathan| url =http://crosscut.com/2008/10/30/religion/18602/ |title=Evangelism meets Seattle: the view from Mars Hill | date = November 30, 2008 | accessdate =April 10, 2014 |work=[[Crosscut.com|Crosscut]]}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.salon.com/2006/11/07/driscoll/|title = The pastor’s wife made him do it|date = November 7, 2006|accessdate = |website = Salon|publisher = |last = Sandler|first = Lauren}} Driscoll later apologized for his statement, stating that he did not intend for his comment to reflect on Haggard's wife personally.{{cite news | url=http://www.seattlepi.com/local/article/Mars-Hill-pastor-responds-to-uproar-over-blog-1221412.php | title=Mars Hill pastor responds to uproar over blog posts on women | work=[[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]] | date=December 3, 2006 | last=Connelly | first=Joel | accessdate=April 8, 2014}} After the incident, the ''Seattle Times'' discontinued Driscoll as one of its religion columnists. === Rant from 2000 === On July 30, 2014, dissenters released a "controversial, vulgar" rant Driscoll had written under the pseudonym "William Wallace II" in 2000, dubbed the "Pussified Nation" rant.{{Cite news|url = http://komonews.com/archive/mars-hill-dissenters-plan-protest-release-vulgar-driscoll-rant|title = Mars Hill: Dissenters plan protest, release vulgar Driscoll rant|last = Connelly|first = Joel|date = July 30, 2014|work = [[Komo News]] / [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]|accessdate = July 21, 2016}} The rant contained "blunt and emotional comments critical of feminism, homosexual behavior, and 'sensitive emasculated' men", and called for "real men" to rise up in the spirit of Scottish warrior [[William Wallace]] as depicted in the film ''[[Braveheart]]''. Mars Hill Church had long since deleted their unmoderated "Midrash" discussion board where the forum postings occurred. Driscoll referenced the incident in his 2006 book ''Confessions of a Reformission Rev'';{{sfn|Driscoll|2006|p = 129}} in that book, he stated that he believed his intentions were "good", but regretted having written the rant. He wrote in 2006, "I had a good mission, but some of my tactics were born out of anger and burnout, and I did a lot of harm and damage while attracting a lot of attention."{{sfn|Driscoll|2006|p = 130}} Driscoll responded to the release of the rant in a letter to his congregation, writing that "the content of my postings to that discussion board does not reflect how I feel or how I would conduct myself today."{{Cite web|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/august/mark-driscoll-crude-comments-william-wallace-mars-hill.html|title = Mark Driscoll Addresses Crude Comments Made Trolling as 'William Wallace II'|date = August 1, 2014|accessdate = August 5, 2014|website = [[Christianity Today]]|publisher = |last = Moon|first = Ruth}} On September 8, 2014, blogger Libby Anne republished other examples of material written by "William Wallace II" in 2001, and remarked she had "rarely seen an evangelical man assert male superiority and prominence this directly."{{Cite news|url = http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2014/09/08/wash-state-megachurch-closes-branches-after-founder-is-caught-calling-women-penis-homes/|title = Wash. state megachurch closes branches after founder is caught calling women ‘penis homes’|last = Edwards|first = David|date = September 8, 2014|work = [[The Raw Story]]|accessdate = September 10, 2014}} === Accusations of plagiarism in ''A Call to Resurgence'' (2013) === On November 21, 2013, radio host Janet Mefferd accused Driscoll of [[plagiarism]]. Mefferd claimed that 14 pages of Driscoll's book ''A Call to Resurgence''{{Sfn|Driscoll|2013b|pp = 45–47, 39}} quoted "extensively and without citation" from Peter Jones's 1999 book, ''Gospel Truth/Pagan Lies: Can You Tell the Difference?''{{cite web |last=Merritt |first=Jonathan |title=Mark Driscoll accused of plagiarism by radio host |website=[[Religion News Service]] |url=http://jonathanmerritt.religionnews.com/2013/11/22/mark-driscoll-accused-plagiarism-radio-host/ |date=November 22, 2013}}{{Cite book|title = Gospel Truth/Pagan Lies: Can You Tell the Difference?|last = Jones|first = Peter R.|publisher = Winepress Publishing/Main Entry Editions|year = 1999|isbn = 9781579212087|location = |pages = 49–54}} and Jones's 2010 book ''One or Two: Seeing a World of Difference.''{{Cite book|title = One or Two: Seeing a World of Difference|last = Jones|first = Peter R.|publisher = Main Entry Editions|year = 2010|isbn = 9780974689524|location = |pages = 17, 88}} Driscoll's publisher [[Tyndale House]] stated that they performed a "thorough in-house review" and disagreed that this was a case of plagiarism. Neil Holdway, a plagiarism expert with the American Copy Editors Society, concluded that "Driscoll had not adequately indicated the extent to which he had borrowed Jones's work."{{Cite web|url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2014/06/30/megachurch-star-mark-driscoll-s-publishing-downfall.html|title = Megachurch Star Mark Driscoll's Publishing Downfall|date = June 30, 2014|accessdate = June 30, 2014|website = [[The Daily Beast]]|publisher = |last = Throckmorton|first = Warren|authorlink = Warren Throckmorton}} More allegations of plagiarism in other Driscoll works soon surfaced, including passages from a sermon series companion text, ''Trial: 8 Witnesses From 1&2 Peter'', which were copied verbatim from passages written by David Wheaton in the ''New Bible Commentary''.{{cite web |last=Merritt |first=Jonathan |title=More allegations of plagiarism surface against Mark Driscoll |website=[[Religion News Service]] |url=http://jonathanmerritt.religionnews.com/2013/11/27/mark-driscoll-silent-amid-mounting-allegations-of-plagiarism/ |date=November 27, 2013}}{{cite web |last=Tracy |first=Kate |date=December 9, 2013 |title=Publisher: Mark Driscoll Improperly Copied Paragraphs from Bible Commentary |website=[[Christianity Today]] |url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2013/december/parsing-mark-driscoll-plagiarism-janet-mefferd-apologizes.html |accessdate= December 10, 2013}} [[InterVarsity Press]], publisher of the ''New Bible Commentary'', stated that Driscoll failed to properly provide quotation or attribution for the material. The relevant passages were posted online.{{cite web |last=Mefferd |first=Janet |title=Page scans of allegedly plagiarized material compared to alleged sources |website=The Janet Mefferd Show |url=http://www.janetmefferd.com/wp-content/uploads/MATERIAL-SCREENSHOTS-HERE.pdf |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203032816/http://www.janetmefferd.com/wp-content/uploads/MATERIAL-SCREENSHOTS-HERE.pdf |archivedate=December 3, 2013}} The allegations soon expanded to include claims that Driscoll used ghostwriters and researchers without giving them proper attribution.{{cite web|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscoll-remains-silent-as-circle-of-plagiarism-accusations-now-includes-questions-on-ghostwriting-john-piper-chimes-in-on-twitter-110596/|title = Mark Driscoll Remains Silent as Circle of Plagiarism Accusations Now Includes Questions on Ghostwriting; John Piper Chimes In on Twitter|date = December 12, 2013|website = [[The Christian Post]]|last = Murashko|first = Alex}}{{Cite web|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2013/december-web-only/real-problem-with-mark-driscolls-citation-errors.html?start=1|title = The Real Problem with Mark Driscoll's 'Citation Errors'|date = December 10, 2013|accessdate = |website = [[Christianity Today]]|publisher = |last = Crouch|first = Andy|quote = No human being could do what "Pastor Mark Driscoll" does—[his] celebrity is actually a complex creation of a whole community of people who sustain the illusion of an impossibly productive, knowledgeable, omnicompetent superhuman.}} As of December 2013, neither Peter Jones, D.A. Carson, nor Janet Mefferd had made any further statements pertaining the case.{{cite web |date=December 4, 2013|title=Basically, Nobody's Talking About the Mark Driscoll Plagiarism Accusations |website=[[Relevant (magazine)|Relevant]] |url=http://www.relevantmagazine.com/slices/basically-nobodys-talking-about-mark-driscoll-plagiarism-accusations}} Syndicator Salem Radio subsequently removed both the broadcast interview with Driscoll and associated materials from Mefferd's program website and apologized for raising the matter in a broadcast interview. This attempt to shut down the story provoked the resignation of Mefferd's producer, Ingrid Schlueter.{{cite web |first=Alex |last=Murashko |title=Fallout From Radio Show Host's Allegations That Pastor Mark Driscoll Plagiarized Includes Deletion, Apology and Producer's Resignation |website=[[The Christian Post]] |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/fallout-from-radio-show-hosts-allegations-that-pastor-mark-driscoll-plagerized-includes-deletion-apology-and-producers-resignation-110271/ |date=December 9, 2013}} In explaining her resignation, Schlueter wrote the following regarding herself and Mefferd: {{bq|text = "I was a part-time, topic producer for Janet Mefferd until [December 3, 2013] when I resigned over this situation. All I can share is that there is an evangelical celebrity machine that is more powerful than anyone realizes. You may not go up against the machine. That is all. Mark Driscoll clearly plagiarized and those who could have underscored the seriousness of it and demanded accountability did not. That is the reality of the evangelical industrial complex."}} Driscoll apologized for "mistakes" related to the allegations in a statement released to ''[[The Christian Post]]'' on December 18, 2013.{{cite news |last=Murashko |first=Alex |date=December 18, 2013 |title=Tyndale House Publishers Defend Mark Driscoll; Seattle-based Megachurch Pastor Apologizes for Mistakes |newspaper=[[The Christian Post]] |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/tyndale-house-publishers-defend-mark-driscoll-seattle-based-megachurch-pastor-apologizes-for-mistakes-111106/ |accessdate=December 18, 2013}} Mefferd eventually left Salem Radio in April 2015. === ''New York Times'' Bestseller List and Driscoll's ''Real Marriage'' (2014) === On March 5, 2014, evangelical magazine ''World'' published an article{{cite web|date=March 5, 2014|accessdate=April 13, 2014 |url=http://www.worldmag.com/2014/03/unreal_sales_for_driscoll_s_real_marriage|title=Unreal sales for Driscoll’s ''Real Marriage''|last=Smith|first=Warren Cole|work=[[World Magazine]]|quote=Seattle’s Mars Hill Church paid a California-based marketing company at least $210,000 in 2011 and 2012 to ensure that ''Real Marriage''... made the ''New York Times'' best-seller list.}} claiming that Mars Hill Church paid a $25,000 fee to marketing firm [[ResultSource]], to manipulate sales numbers{{cite news|date=February 22, 2013| last=Trachtenberg|first=Jeffrey A.|title=The Mystery of the Book Sales Spike: How Are Some Authors Landing On Best-Seller Lists? They're Buying Their Way|url=https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424127887323864304578316143623600544|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]]|accessdate=April 7, 2014}} of Mark Driscoll's book ''Real Marriage'' and thereby attain a place on the [[The New York Times Best Seller list|''New York Times'' bestseller list]].{{cite web |url=http://www.latimes.com/books/jacketcopy/la-et-jc-pastor-contract-resultsource-bestseller-lists-20140305,0,7039368.story#axzz2vCwCm0fo |title=Can bestseller lists be bought? |work=[[LA Times]] |first=Carolyn|last=Kellogg |date=March 6, 2014 |accessdate=March 7, 2014|quote=[Mars Hill Church] paid an estimated $210,000 to ResultSource to make ''Real Marriage'' a bestseller...}}{{cite web |url=http://www.mhpbooks.com/got-200000-congratulations-youre-a-bestselling-author/ |title=Got $200,000? Congratulations, you’re a bestselling author. |publisher=[[Melville House Publishing]] |first=Julia|last=Fleischaker |date=March 7, 2014 |accessdate=March 7, 2014}} ResultSource accomplished this objective—the book briefly reached #1 in the "Advice How-to" category—by buying 11,000 copies of the book, using $210,000 of Mars Hill Church's money,{{cite web|url=http://slog.thestranger.com/slog/archives/2014/03/11/mars-hill-church-admits-to-buying-pastor-mark-driscoll-a-spot-on-the-new-york-times-bestseller-list|title=Mars Hill Church Admits To Buying Pastor Mark Driscoll a Spot on the New York Times Bestseller List|website = [[The Stranger (newspaper)|The Stranger]]|last = Constant|first = Paul|date = March 11, 2014}} from a variety of online sources and payment methods.{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/best-sellers-books/2012-01-22/hardcover-advice/list.html | accessdate =March 16, 2012 | title = Best seller books | date = January 22, 2012 |quote = Hardcover advice | type = list | newspaper = The New York Times}} The [[Evangelical Council for Financial Accountability]] stated that buying a place on bestseller lists violates its ethical standards, but that because this happened before Mars Hill Church joined they were unable to take action.{{cite web|url=https://www.theatlantic.com/business/archive/2014/03/can-megachurches-deal-with-mega-money-in-a-christian-way/284379/|title = Can Megachurches Deal With Mega Money in a Christian Way?|last = Graham|first = Ruth|date = March 14, 2014|website = [[The Atlantic]]}} ''Christianity Today'' described the arrangement as "ethically questionable",{{cite web|last=Tracy|first=Kate|title=Mars Hill Defends How Mark Driscoll's 'Real Marriage' Became a Bestseller|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/march/did-mark-driscoll-real-marriage-earn-nyt-bestseller-status-.html|work=[[Christianity Today]]|accessdate=April 7, 2014}} and Carl Trueman of religion journal ''[[First Things]]'' decried the revelation, writing, "the overall picture is one of disaster" and "[it] has raised questions not simply about personal integrity but also the very culture of American Evangelicalism."{{cite web|url = http://www.firstthings.com/web-exclusives/2014/03/mark-driscolls-problems-and-ours|title = Mark Driscoll's Problems, and Ours: The Crisis of Leadership in American Evangelicalism|last = Trueman|first = Carl R.|date = March 14, 2014|website = [[First Things]]|publisher = The Institute on Religion and Public Life}} Driscoll had used the apparent success of ''Real Marriage'' to negotiate a multi-book deal with Christian publisher Tyndale House. The first book under Driscoll's "Resurgence" [[imprint (trade name)|imprint]] was ''A Call to Resurgence,'' with plans to publish five to seven books per year. Tyndale House defended Driscoll's alleged plagiarism in ''A Call to Resurgence'', and affirmed their continuing relationship with Driscoll. Mars Hill Church responded with a statement,{{cite web|title=A Note From Our Board of Advisors & Accountability|url=http://marshill.com/2014/03/07/a-note-from-our-board-of-advisors-accountability|publisher=[[Mars Hill Church]]|accessdate=April 15, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140411044436/http://marshill.com/2014/03/07/a-note-from-our-board-of-advisors-accountability|archivedate=April 11, 2014|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} writing, "while not uncommon or illegal, this unwise strategy [of buying one's own books to drive up book sales figures] is not one we had used before or since, and not one we will use again." Mars Hill also claimed that the "true cost" of the effort was less than "what has been reported." On March 17, 2014, Driscoll posted an open letter of apology in response to this controversy and others, writing that he will no longer claim to be a ''New York Times'' bestselling author, and that he now sees the ResultSource marketing campaign as "manipulating a book sales reporting system, which is wrong."{{cite news|last=Weber|first=Jeremy|title=Mark Driscoll Retracts Bestseller Book Status, Resets Life|url=http://www.christianitytoday.com/gleanings/2014/march/mark-driscoll-retracts-bestseller-status-resets-life.html|accessdate=April 15, 2014|newspaper=[[Christianity Today]]|date=March 17, 2014}} He wrote that he was giving up his status as a "celebrity pastor", that he considered his "angry young prophet" days to be over, and that he was reducing his public presence in speaking engagements and on social media.{{cite web |date=March 17, 2014|title=Mark Driscoll Posts an Open Letter of Apology |website=[[Relevant (magazine)|Relevant]] |url=http://www.relevantmagazine.com/god/church/mark-driscoll-posts-open-letter-apology}} On March 28, 2015, Sutton Turner, a former elder of the church who signed the Result Source contract, explained that he disapproved of the marketing plan to use Result Source, but the decision to use it had already been made before he began work at Mars Hill, so he signed the contract anyway.{{cite web|url = http://www.christiantoday.com/article/former.mars.hill.elder.gives.inside.story.of.controversial.plan.to.boost.mark.driscolls.book.sales/52669.htm|title = Former Mars Hill elder gives inside story of controversial plan to boost Mark Driscoll's book sales|date = April 23, 2015|website = Christianity Today|last = Woods|first = Mark}} === Planned appearance at Hillsong Conference 2015 === Driscoll was scheduled to appear at [[Hillsong Church]]'s 2015 Australian and UK conferences. A petition against Driscoll's appearance at the conference collected 3000 signatures, prompting Hillsong Church Senior Pastor [[Brian Houston (pastor)|Brian Houston]] to cancel Driscoll's planned speaking event.{{Cite web|title = Hillsong church drops controversial US preacher Mark Driscoll from conferences|url = https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/jun/07/hillsong-church-drops-controversial-us-preacher-mark-driscoll-from-conferences|website = the Guardian|accessdate = July 28, 2015|first = Michael|last = Safi|date = June 7, 2015}} Instead, the Hillsong conference presented a 30-minute taped interview of Mark and Grace Driscoll interviewed by Houston at the conference.{{Cite web|title = Mark Driscoll interviewed at Hillsong Conference despite promises he'd been dropped|url = http://www.christiantoday.com/article/mark.driscoll.interviewed.at.hillsong.conference.despite.promises.hed.been.dropped/57641.htm|website = Christian Today|accessdate = July 28, 2015|last = Gledhill|first = Ruth|date = June 30, 2015}} == Beliefs == [[File:Mars Hill Church, Ballard location, worship band stage.jpg|thumb|The indie-rock worship band's soundstage at Mars Hill Church's Ballard location (2013)]] Driscoll is an evangelical Christian. Within that broad movement, he is [[Conservative Evangelicalism|theologically]] and socially conservative. On the [[Bible]], he is a [[Biblical literalism|literalist]] and [[Inerrancy and Infallibility of Bible|inerrantist]]. Driscoll's theology draws inspiration from historical theologians, including [[St. Augustine]], [[John Calvin]], and [[Martin Luther]], along with the [[Puritans]], [[Jonathan Edwards (theologian)|Jonathan Edwards]], and [[Charles Spurgeon]].{{cite web | url=http://theresurgence.com/2008/07/28/recap-spurgeon-is-the-man-week | title=Recap: Spurgeon is the Man Week | publisher=[[Mars Hill Church]] | work=[[The Resurgence (organization)|The Resurgence]] | type=blog | date=July 28, 2008 | accessdate=December 9, 2012 | last=Driscoll | first=Mark | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121231063327/http://theresurgence.com/2008/07/28/recap-spurgeon-is-the-man-week | archivedate=December 31, 2012 | df=mdy-all }} He also respects evangelical leaders such as [[Billy Graham]], [[J. I. Packer]], [[Francis Schaeffer]], and [[John Stott]]. His contemporary influences include [[Lesslie Newbigin]]{{Cite thesis|last = Stewart|first = Joe Randall|title = The Influence of Newbigin's Missiology on Selected Innovators and Early Adopters of the Emerging Church Paradigm|url = http://hdl.handle.net/10392/4519|date = December 30, 2013|type = Doctor of Education|publisher = [[Southern Baptist Theological Seminary]]}} and the group he terms the "Missional Reformed Evangelicals": [[Don Carson]] and [[John Piper (theologian)|John Piper]] for theology, and [[Timothy J. Keller|Tim Keller]] and [[Ed Stetzer]] for missiology.{{harvnb|Driscoll|2009|p=216}} ''cited in'' {{Cite book|title = Crossroads: An Exploration of the Emerging-missional Conversation with a Special Focus on 'missional Leadership' and Its Challenges for Theological Education|last = Doomenbal|first = Robert J. A.|publisher = Eburon Uitgeverij B.V.|year = 2012|isbn = 9789059726239|location = |page = 42}} {{cite web | url = http://www.patheos.com/blogs/adrianwarnock/2006/04/interview-with-mark-driscoll_02/ | title = Interview with Mark Driscoll | date = April 2, 2006 | accessdate= December 9, 2012 | last = Warnock | first = Adrian}} Driscoll's combination of theological conservatism and his "missional" embrace of contemporary culture contribute to controversies. Molly Worthen wrote: "Conservatives call Driscoll 'the cussing pastor' and wish that he'd trade in his fashionably distressed jeans and taste for indie rock for a suit and tie and placid choral arrangements. Liberals wince at his hellfire theology and insistence that women submit to their husbands." Regarding [[spiritual gifts]], Driscoll is a [[Continuationism|continuationist]].{{Cite news|title = John MacArthur vs. Mark Driscoll: Megachurch pastors clash over charismatic theology|date = October 18, 2013|url = http://www.religionnews.com/2013/10/18/john-macarthur-vs-mark-driscoll-megachurch-pastors-clash-charismatic-theology/|last = Bailey|first = Sarah Pulliam|work = [[Religion News Service]]|quote = Driscoll, who pastors Mars Hill Church in Seattle, is a reformed pastor who is more open to charismatic theology.}}{{cite web | url = http://pastormark.tv/2011/12/15/tough-text-thursday-1-corinthians-13 | title = Tough Text Thursday: 1 Corinthians 13 | last = Driscoll | first = Mark | date = December 15, 2011 | type = blog | quote = At Mars Hill Church, this is why we say we’re "Charismatic with a seat belt." | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140502041439/http://pastormark.tv/2011/12/15/tough-text-thursday-1-corinthians-13 | archivedate = May 2, 2014 | df = mdy-all }} Regarding creation, he is a "Historic [[Creationism|Creationist]]".{{Cite book|title = Doctrine: What Christians Should Believe|authors = Mark Driscoll, Gerry Breshears|publisher = Crossway|year = 2010|isbn = 978-1433527579|pages = 93|quote = "We hold to historic creationism, which emphasizes that the first two chapters of Genesis, God’s inspired and inerrant Word, tell us that the God who created everything (angels, space-time, mass-energy, sun, moon, and stars, and all species of animals) prepared the land for human habitation in six literal twenty-four-hour days. At the end of those days, he shaped dust and breathed the breath of life into it, creating Adam. From Adam’s rib, God created the woman."}} In his book ''Doctrine: What Christians Should Believe'', Driscoll expressed his respect for [[John Sailhamer]]'s book ''Genesis Unbound''; Driscoll is skeptical of [[Theistic evolution|evolution as a part of creationism]].{{cite web|url = http://theresurgence.com/2006/07/03/answers-to-common-questions-about-creation|title = Answers to common questions about creation|last = Driscoll|first = Mark|date = July 3, 2006|website = [[The Resurgence (organization)|The Resurgence]]|quote = However, as Christians we are not free to accept the yet unproven and highly suspect thesis of macro-evolution that one species can evolve into another species entirely.|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121005123543/http://theresurgence.com/2006/07/03/answers-to-common-questions-about-creation|archivedate = October 5, 2012|df = mdy-all}} Driscoll believes that homosexual behavior is sinful,{{cite web|last=Driscoll|first=Mark|title=Mark Driscoll on Piers Morgan | type = transcript|url= http://thegospelcoalition.org/blogs/trevinwax/2012/03/10/mark-driscoll-on-piers-morgan-transcript/ |last2=Morgan|first2=Piers|authorlink2=Piers Morgan|date=March 10, 2012|quote= Homosexuality is wrong}} and that marriage is between one man and one woman.{{cite web|last=Driscoll|first=Mark|title=Answers to Common Questions about Creation|url=http://theresurgence.com/2006/07/03/answers-to-common-questions-about-creation|work=[[The Resurgence (organization)|The Resurgence]]|location=Was anything made not good?|date=July 3, 2006|quote=Importantly, it was God who created the covenant of marriage, thus He alone defines what it is. His definition of one man and one woman eliminates any alternatives such as bestiality, homosexuality, and polygamy|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121005123543/http://theresurgence.com/2006/07/03/answers-to-common-questions-about-creation|archivedate=October 5, 2012|df=mdy-all}} On church government, Driscoll favors an [[Elder (Christianity)|elder]]-led approach. === Calvinism === Driscoll adheres to [[Reformed theology|Reformed]] or [[Calvinism|Calvinist]] theology, although he characterizes his position specifically as [[New Calvinism]] to differentiate himself from the more [[cessationist]] and non-[[Missional living|missional]] aspects associated historically with Calvinism.{{cite web|url = http://theresurgence.com/2009/03/12/time-magazine-names-new-calvinism-3rd-most-powerful-idea|title = ''TIME'' magazine names New Calvinism 3rd most powerful idea|last = Driscoll|website = [[The Resurgence (organization)|The Resurgence]]|first = Mark|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20121113162916/http://theresurgence.com/2009/03/12/time-magazine-names-new-calvinism-3rd-most-powerful-idea|archivedate = November 13, 2012|df = mdy-all}}{{cite web|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2006/julyweb-only/127-52.0.html?paging=off|title = Men Are from Mars Hill|last = Bailey|first = Jason|date = July 4, 2006|website = [[Christianity Today]]}} Driscoll denies the orthodox [[Calvinist]] view of [[Limited Atonement|limited atonement]] and believes instead that Jesus died for ''all people'' in some sense, and for ''some people'' (the elect) in another sense.{{cite web | url = https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:URkA9lL6Tu0J:assets.marshillchurch.org/media/2005/11/20/20051120_unlimited-limited-atonement_document.pdf+Driscoll+limited+unlimited+atonement&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEEShEzho9WbrCsLn2bmtfGUNC7Dm3cmF3AoMPvieBF7ZKsMDhH8yCz3sMJdRAoc46le5tDJN965Wj-hIUchNJuh7b71hwbKynsISVAgCxYk0hlZVKykleFQLf3fKRNXIHM0E1iLjc&sig=AHIEtbTyZCUbz0lPliwePg83Too9J-FjkQ | title = Unlimited-Limited Atonement | type = sermon notes | date = November 20, 2005 | last = Driscoll | first = Mark}}{{cite AV media | last = Driscoll | first = Mark | url = http://www.marshillchurch.org/Audio/Atonement8_Driscoll_112005.mp3 | archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20070927200843/http://www.marshillchurch.org/Audio/Atonement8_Driscoll_112005.mp3 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2007-09-27 | title = Unlimited-Limited Atonement | type = audio | format = [[MP3]] | at = 44–50 min }} He thinks this position was what [[John Calvin]] believed, saying in a humorous tone: 'Calvinism came after Calvin... I will argue that the Calvinists are not very Calvin. I will argue against Calvinism with Calvin... What kind of Calvinist are you? I'm a Calvin, not a Calvinist, that came later'. Driscoll also believes that this position (or slight variations thereof) was held by men like [[Charles Spurgeon]], [[John Bunyan]], [[Martin Luther]], and [[Richard Baxter]]. Driscoll distinguishes between [[Predestination (Calvinism)|double and single predestination]], and says that unlike [[John Calvin]], he believes only in single predestination.{{cite AV media | publisher = [[Mars Hill Church]] | url = http://www.marshillchurch.org/media/religionsaves | chapter = Part 3 | type = sermon | title = Predestination | minutes = 8 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090721151116/http://www.marshillchurch.org/media/religionsaves | archivedate = July 21, 2009 | df = mdy-all }} through the sermon he talks briefly about this. === Emerging church === Driscoll was associated with the [[emerging church]] movement. He described the movement as follows:{{harvnb|Driscoll|2006|p=22}}. ''Cited in'' {{Cite journal|title = Perspicuity of Scripture: The Emergent Approach|journal = [[Master's Seminary|Master's Seminary Journal]]|volume = 17|issue = 2|last = MacArthur|first = John F.|authorlink = John F. MacArthur|year = 2006|url = http://www.tms.edu/tmsj/tmsj17g.pdf|issn = 1066-3959|pages = 12–13|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100624213346/http://www.tms.edu/tmsj/tmsj17g.pdf|archivedate = June 24, 2010|df = mdy-all}}
The emerging church is a growing, loosely connected movement of primarily young pastors who are glad to see the end of modernity and are seeking to function as missionaries who bring the gospel of Jesus Christ to emerging and postmodern cultures. The emerging church welcomes the tension of holding in one closed hand the unchanging truth of evangelical Christian theology ({{bibleref2|Jude 3}}) and holding in one open hand the many cultural ways of showing and speaking Christian truth as a missionary to America ({{bibleref2|1 Cor|9:19–23}}). Since the movement, if it can be called that, is young and is still defining its theological center, I do not want to portray the movement as ideologically unified because I myself swim in the theologically conservative stream of the emerging church.
Driscoll later distanced himself from the movement:{{cite web | last = Driscoll | first = Mark | title = Welcome | url = http://theresurgence.com/?q=node/5 | accessdate = July 11, 2010 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110524085722/http://theresurgence.com/?q=node%2F5 | archivedate = May 24, 2011 | df = mdy-all }}
In the mid-1990s I was part of what is now known as the [[emerging church]] and spent some time traveling the country to speak on the emerging church in the emerging culture on a team put together by Leadership Network called the Young Leader Network. But, I eventually had to distance myself from the emergent stream of the network because friends like [[Brian McLaren]] and [[Doug Pagitt]] began pushing a theological agenda that greatly troubled me. Examples include referring to [[Gender of God in Christianity|God as a chick]], questioning [[Attributes of God in Christianity#Sovereignty|God's sovereignty]] over and [[open theism|knowledge of the future]], denial of the [[substitutionary atonement]] at the cross, a low view of Scripture, and denial of [[hell]] which is one hell of a mistake.
=== Gender roles === On gender roles, Driscoll is a [[Complementarianism|complementarian]], believing that men and women have equal worth, but have different roles within the family and the church. He endorses male headship of the home and church. According to a ''Mother Jones'' profile on Driscoll in 1998, he may have held [[Christian egalitarianism|egalitarian]] views at one time. He offered church courses in "evangelical feminism" and is quoted as saying "the Bible is clear that men and women are both created by God in His image and likeness and totally equal in every way." In 2003, Driscoll said that he wished he could change the parts of the Bible that he believes restrict women from being pastors. Male leadership of the church is crucial, according to Driscoll, who believes that God called him specifically to "train men." He traces many modern spiritual and social problems to the acceptance of female leadership. Driscoll describes Eve's temptation by the serpent in the [[Garden of Eden]] as "the first invitation to an independent feminism." For Eve to eat the forbidden fruit was, according to Driscoll, "the first exercising of a woman's role in leadership in the home and in the church in the history of the world. It does not go well." Driscoll believes that Christianity has been "feminized." In a 2006 interview with ''Desiring God'', he said, "The problem with the church today, it's just a bunch of nice, soft, tender, 'chickified' [''sic''] church boys. Sixty percent of Christians are chicks, and the forty percent that are dudes are still sort of chicks.... The whole architecture and the whole aesthetic [of church buildings and services] is really feminine."{{Cite video| people = Mark Driscoll (interviewee), Josh Brage (contributor)| title = Church Needs Dudes| accessdate = May 5, 2005| date = April 14, 2006 | time = 120 seconds| url = https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=lex6orNNzTs}} In contrast, Driscoll emphasizes what he perceives as macho behavior in the actions of biblical protagonists: he describes [[Jesus]], [[Paul the Apostle]], and [[David|King David]] saying: "... these guys were dudes. Heterosexual, win-a-fight, punch-you-in-the-nose, dudes." He believes that in order to be innovative, the church needs to get entrepreneurial young men involved, who will "make the culture of the future." Driscoll interprets the Apostle Paul as writing that women are encouraged to be an active part of life and ministry in the church, but that only men can teach other men or become "[[Elder (Christianity)|elder]]-pastors" (the terms being synonymous). Since Paul's prohibition of female elder-pastors appeals to the Genesis creation story ({{bibleref2|1 Timothy|2:14}}) for its rationale, Driscoll argues that the restriction is permanent and cannot be adjusted for changing culture.{{Cite web|url = http://pastormark.tv/2011/09/20/faq-women-and-ministry|title = FAQ: Women and Ministry|date = September 20, 2011|accessdate = August 1, 2014|website = pastormark.tv|publisher = |last = Driscoll|first = Mark|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140806213738/http://pastormark.tv/2011/09/20/faq-women-and-ministry|archivedate = August 6, 2014|df = mdy-all}} When the [[Episcopal Church (United States)|Episcopal Church]] elected [[Katharine Jefferts Schori]] as its first female [[Presiding Bishop]], Driscoll wrote on his blog that "if Christian males do not man up soon, the Episcopalians may vote a fluffy baby bunny rabbit as their next bishop to lead God's men."{{Cite web| last = Connelly| first = Joel| title = New bishop brings wit to the job| work = [[Seattle Post-Intelligencer]]| date = September 4, 2007| accessdate = May 5, 2014| url = http://www.seattlepi.com/local/connelly/article/New-bishop-brings-wit-to-the-job-1248678.php#src=fb}} === Sexuality === {{main|Real Marriage}} According to Salon.com, "Driscoll has been a key advocate for candid conversations about sexuality among conservative Christians". Mark and Grace Driscoll published their first book together, entitled ''Real Marriage: The Truth About Sex, Friendship & Life Together'', in January 2012. It includes a chapter entitled "Can We ___?", discussing a biblical rationale for specific sexual acts that evangelical pastors are considered reluctant to discuss.{{Cite news|title = Mark Driscoll's 'Real Marriage' Draws Controversy for 'Invasive' Sex Talk|date = January 9, 2012|last = Mohammed|first = Ravelle|url = http://www.christianpost.com/news/mark-driscolls-real-marriage-draws-controversy-for-invasive-sex-talk-66609/|work = [[Christian Post]]}} Driscoll said that the book was written because "only two [Christian] books go into depth on sexuality... a lot of Christian teaching about sex is answering questions of a previous generation."{{Cite web|url = http://www.christianitytoday.com/ct/2012/januaryweb-only/mark-driscoll-sex-marriage.html|title = Q & A: Mark and Grace Driscoll on Sex for the 21st-Century Christian|date = January 5, 2012|website = [[Christianity Today]]|last = Beaty|first = Katelyn|last2 = Graves|first2 = Marlena}} The Driscolls and Mars Hill Church heavily promoted the book, taking interviews with ''[[The View (U.S. TV series)|The View]]'', ''[[Fox & Friends]]'', and ''[[Piers Morgan Tonight]].''{{Cite web|url = http://pastormark.tv/2012/03/16/the-new-york-media-tour|title = The New York Media Tour|website = Pastor Mark Driscoll|date = March 16, 2012|last = Driscoll|first = Mark|type = blog|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140501092900/http://pastormark.tv/2012/03/16/the-new-york-media-tour|archivedate = May 1, 2014|df = mdy-all}} ''[[The Daily Beast]]'' described the book as controversial, writing that "evangelicals of all stripes [were] outraged... from conservatives shocked by the graphic sex descriptions to liberals who hate its degrading of women."{{Cite news|title = Mark Driscoll’s Sex Manual ‘Real Marriage’ Scandalizes Evangelicals|date = January 13, 2012|last = Sessions|first = David|url = http://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2012/01/13/mark-driscoll-s-sex-manual-real-marriage-scandalizes-evangelicals.html|work = [[The Daily Beast]]}} According to ''[[The Daily Mail]]'', the book "gives a green light to a range of sexual taboos such as anal sex and using sex toys", thereby taking aim at conservative religious views on sexual acts.{{Cite news|title = Evangelical pastor under fire from Christians over sexually-explicit guide to marriage|date = January 10, 2012|url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-2084815/Evangelical-pastor-Christians-sexually-explicit-guide-marriage.html#ixzz30S1SJWFz|last = Dumas|first = Daisy|newspaper = [[The Daily Mail]]}} {{italic title}} {{Penance and Reconciliation}} '''''Misericordia Dei''''' (''Mercy of God'') is the title of an [[apostolic letter]] by [[Pope John Paul II]] to foster and reemphasize the importance of the ''[[Sacrament of Reconciliation]]''. The letter is subtitled "''On Certain Aspects of the Sacrament of Penance''" and was promulgated on 7 April 2002 in [[Rome]], issued as [[Motu proprio]] and was signed by him.<ref>''OSV's encyclopedia of Catholic history'' by Matthew Bunson 2004 {{ISBN|1-59276-026-0}} page 509</ref><ref>''John Paul II: a light for the world'' by Mary Ann Walsh 2003 {{ISBN|1-58051-142-2}} page 242</ref>
The letter begins by quoting the [[Gospel of Matthew]] {{bibleverse-nb||Matthew|1:21|NIV}} that [[Jesus]] was born to "save his people from their sins" and emphasizes the fervent and energetic summons with which [[John the Baptist]] called for repentance. Quoting the [[Epistle to the Romans]] {{bibleverse-nb||Romans|8:21|NIV}}, it states that "Salvation is therefore and above all redemption from sin, which hinders friendship with God."
The letter emphasizes that Jesus himself granted the Apostles, through the power of the [[Holy Spirit]], the authority to reconcile repentant sinners with God and the Church and quotes the [[Gospel of John]] {{bibleverse-nb||John|20:22-23|NIV}}: “Receive the Holy Spirit. If you forgive the sins of any, they are forgiven; if you retain the sins of any, they are retained”.
The letter states that the [[Sacrament of Reconciliation]] entails not only the action of the minister – only a Bishop or priest, who judges and absolves, tends and heals in the name of Christ – but also the actions of the penitent: contrition, confession and satisfaction. The letter emphasizes the need for penitents to "name their own sins", except when this is not possible.
As in the year 2000 letter [[Novo Millennio Ineunte]] John Paul II again asked the clergy for "renewed pastoral courage in ensuring that the day-to-day teaching of Christian communities persuasively and effectively presents the practice of the Sacrament of Reconciliation".
